message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the epigastric mass suggests pyloric stenosis. The best diagnostic test for pyloric stenosis is an abdominal ultrasound that shows an elongated and thickened pylorus. Serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone concentration is used to diagnose congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which is not related to this case. Dilated colon segment on abdominal x-ray and corkscrew sign on upper gastrointestinal contrast series are associated with malrotation and volvulus, but these conditions usually present with bilious vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest pyloric stenosis, which can be confirmed by an abdominal ultrasound that will show an elongated and thickened pylorus. High serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone concentration suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Dilated colon segment on abdominal x-ray and corkscrew sign on upper gastrointestinal contrast series suggest malrotation with volvulus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of recurrent nonbilious vomiting after feeding and a 2-cm epigastric mass suggest hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The most appropriate diagnostic evaluation is an abdominal ultrasound, which will show elongation and thickening of the pylorus. High serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone concentration suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia, dilated colon segment on abdominal x-ray suggests Hirschsprung disease, and corkscrew sign on upper gastrointestinal contrast series suggests malrotation with volvulus, which are not consistent with the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of nonbilious vomiting after feeding in a 5-week-old male infant with a 2-cm epigastric mass are consistent with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). Further diagnostic evaluation is most likely to show an elongated and thickened pylorus on abdominal ultrasound. Options A, B, and D are not associated with IHPS.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of nonbilious vomiting in a 5-week-old infant suggest pyloric stenosis. An elongated and thickened pylorus is characteristic of pyloric stenosis and can be seen on abdominal ultrasound. High serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone concentration is seen in congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Dilated colon segment on abdominal x-ray suggests Hirschsprung disease. Corkscrew sign on upper gastrointestinal contrast series is seen in midgut volvulus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest pyloric stenosis, which causes vomiting after feeding. The physical examination finding of a 2-cm epigastric mass is consistent with pyloric muscle hypertrophy. The most likely diagnostic test to confirm this diagnosis is abdominal ultrasound, which can show an elongated and thickened pylorus. Option A is a marker of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which can present with vomiting but is not likely in this case. Option B is a sign of Hirschsprung disease, which is characterized by an absence of ganglion cells in the colon and is not related to this patient's symptoms. Option D is a sign of malrotation, which can cause vomiting but is less likely given the presentation and physical exam findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of recurrent nonbilious vomiting and a 2-cm epigastric mass suggest pyloric stenosis. Abdominal ultrasound is the best diagnostic test to detect the elongated and thickened pylorus. High serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone concentration is specific for congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and dilated colon segment on abdominal x-ray and corkscrew sign on upper gastrointestinal contrast series are signs of intestinal obstruction, which are not consistent with the symptoms and physical examination findings in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of nonbilious vomiting after feeding and the presence of an epigastric mass suggests pyloric stenosis, which can be diagnosed through abdominal ultrasound by observing the elongated and thickened pylorus. High serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone concentration suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which does not fit the clinical presentation. Dilated colon segment and corkscrew sign are associated with intestinal malrotation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptom presented is consistent with pyloric stenosis, and option C describes an elongated and thickened pylorus, which is commonly seen in this condition. The other options are not associated with pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of recurrent vomiting in a male infant along with a visible epigastric mass are suggestive of pyloric stenosis, which can be confirmed through abdominal ultrasound. High serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone concentration indicates congenital adrenal hyperplasia, dilated colon segment on abdominal x-ray indicates Hirschsprung disease, and corkscrew sign on upper gastrointestinal contrast series suggests malrotation with volvulus. None of these conditions fit the given symptoms and physical findings of the patient.
